--- Jim Cheesman <jchees@...> wrote:
> * You've written your test. You've implemented your feature. The test
> fails... Why?

Did I say not to use a debugger to debug? I don't think I did. I said
that I think the advice to always run the debugger on every line of
code one writes (as quoted from Code Complete) is not applicable when
one does test first programming.

> * You've inherited some code from someone. It's badly named, barely 
> commented, undocumented, and there are no unit tests. What does it
> do?

Of course, when the assumed test first approach (which I *thought* I
explicitly stated) is missing, a debugger may be helpful. I've actually
found it more useful to convert the untested code by adding tests and
design by contract assertions.

Debuggers are not inherently evil. Personally, I find little use for
them, but they are not inherently evil. I recognize that my personal
lack of desire or need for a debugger does not mean that everyone else
should share my attitude. Nonetheless, I find that the Code Complete
advice (practically a demand) to always run a debugger on every line of
code one writes is simply inappropriate in a test first design.

Regards,

Rob
